channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Paris: One Year On
item.media:description: A wounded man was evacuated at the Bataclan concert hall on Nov. 13, 2015. In all, 90 people were killed in the attack there.
item.description: This is the story of the Paris attacks by those who lived through them. “I will always live with the fact that I saw ringing cellphones that said ‘Papa,’ ‘Maman,’ on the dead.”
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: How Do You Tell the Story of the Paris Attacks? You Let Survivors Speak
item.media:description: People gathered outside the Notre Dame Cathedral on Nov. 15, 2015.
item.description: Alissa J. Rubin, The Times’s Paris bureau chief, describes how compiling an oral history project on the 2015 attacks revealed new aspects of the traumatic event.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: U.K.’s Bridge to Trump? Nigel Farage, Who Pushed ‘Brexit,’ Posits Himself
item.media:description: Nigel Farage, right, the acting leader of the U.K. Independence Party, arrived at Trump Tower in New York on Saturday.
item.description: Mr. Farage was the first foreign politician to meet with President-elect Donald J. Trump, and on Monday, a photograph of the two inside Trump Tower dominated front pages in Britain.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Putin and Trump Talk on Phone and Agree to Improve Ties, Kremlin Says
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Berlin in October. He and President-elect Donald J. Trump spoke about Syria during a call on Monday.
item.description: The leaders discussed trade and combating terrorism, with the Russian president saying he hoped for “noninterference in the other’s internal affairs.”
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: U.S. Fingerprints on Attacks Obliterating Yemen’s Economy
item.media:description: The remains of a factory, owned by the brothers Khalid and Abdullah Alsonidar, that was bombed twice in September outside Yemen’s capital, Sana.
item.description: The Saudi-led coalition is hitting civilian targets, like factories, bridges and power stations, that critics say have no clear link to the rebels. In the rubble, the remains of American munitions have been found.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Israel’s Right, Cheering Donald Trump’s Win, Renews Calls to Abandon 2-State Solution
item.media:description: A Tel Aviv cafe on Wednesday. “The era of a Palestinian state is over,” one cabinet minister said after the United States election.
item.description: Rightist politicians see Mr. Trump’s victory as a chance to reverse course on contentious policies like building new settlements and accords with the Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: U.S. Forces May Have Committed War Crimes in Afghanistan, Prosecutor Says
item.description: The International Criminal Court signaled Monday that investigations were likely in cases involving American and Afghan soldiers, as well as Taliban fighters.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA and MARLISE SIMONS
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Kashmir Is Paralyzed by an ‘Adored’ Band of Militants
item.media:description: Kashmiri women in mourning this month in Srinagar.
item.description: The militants have widespread support from a populace that has lost faith in dialogue to resolve differences with the Indian government.
item.dc:creator: GEETA ANAND and HARI KUMAR

item.title: With Odes to Military March, China Puts Nationalism Into Overdrive
item.media:description: A performance in Beijing of “The Long March,” a new opera that celebrates the early days of the Chinese Communist Party.
item.description: Beijing is using the anniversary of the Long March, which established Mao’s pre-eminence, in an effort to sow patriotic fervor and strengthen loyalty to the Communist Party.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: After Trump’s Win, an Anxious Mexico Asks: What’s Next?
item.media:description: A fence separating Mexico and the United States, in Tijuana, Mexico. During his campaign, Donald J. Trump vowed to deport millions of immigrants and build a wall along the entirety of the border.
item.description: Clouds have descended over Mexico, miring the nation in a state of anguish and paralysis over what the incoming United States president has in store for it.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: Nairobi Journal: As Grasslands Dwindle, Kenya’s Shepherds Seek Urban Pastures
item.media:description: Allan Lemayian’s cattle grazed along a road this month in the Langata neighborhood of Nairobi, Kenya.
item.media:credit: Andrew Renneisen for The New York Times
item.description: Drought conditions, metropolitan sprawl and shrinking pastureland have driven some herders to graze their flocks in the country’s capital.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: What in the World: In China, One Music Website Is Always No. 1
item.media:description: Douban.com is essential to China’s growing music scene. The site attracts more than 40 percent of Chinese internet users every month.
item.description: The Chinese market is dominated by Douban, which exposes users to thousands of bands around the world and is essential to China’s own music scene.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL GRIFFITHS

item.title: 76 Experts Urge Donald Trump to Keep Iran Deal
item.media:description: Worshippers attend Friday prayer in Tehran last week. Donald Trump has called the nuclear agreement with Iran a foreign-policy disaster.
item.description: A report signed by scholars and former officials asked the president-elect to use the deal, which he has called a disaster, to further ease tensions with Iran.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: How India Plans to Wipe Out ‘Black Money’
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi has banned 500- and 1,000-rupee bills, or about 86 percent of India’s currency, in an effort to combat corruption and tax avoidance.
item.dc:creator: GEETA ANAND

item.title: Russian Jet Crashes Off Syria While Trying to Land on Carrier Kuznetsov
item.description: The Russian Defense Ministry blamed a technical failure for the crash of the jet, a MIG-29.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Greece, Seeking Dose of Stability, Is Rattled by Trump’s Win
item.media:description: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece is hoping to win a new round of debt relief from creditors before Donald J. Trump takes office.
item.description: A failure to secure debt relief before 2017 could spell a new round of political and economic instability in the country, and Europe as a whole.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN and NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: Poland Exhumes Ex-President’s Body in Inquiry of 2010 Plane Crash
item.media:description: Wreckage from the plane crash that killed 96 people, including President Lech Kaczynski, in Smolensk, Russia, in April 2010.
item.description: The remains of President Lech Kaczynski, his wife and other victims are to be re-examined, but critics say the investigation is politically motivated.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA BERENDT

item.title: Globalism: A Far-Right Conspiracy Theory Buoyed by Trump
item.media:description: A scene from President-elect Donald Trump’s campaign event in West Palm Beach, Fla., in October. The Anti-Defamation League criticized the speech for “evoking classic anti-Semitic themes.”
item.description: Analysts who track U.S. extremist groups have expressed alarm at the president-elect’s use of the word, a staple of antigovernment conspiracy theories.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: 2016 Likely to Top 2015 as Hottest Year on Record, Scientists Say
item.description: The announcement is no surprise to climate scientists, as experts at NASA had already projected that the year would be the third bringing record heat.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Trump and Xi Jinping, China’s Leader, Hold Cordial First Phone Call
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing last week.
item.description: The president-elect skipped the harsh rhetoric on trade used in the campaign and predicted “one of the strongest relationships” for the U.S. and China.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Assange Is Questioned in London Over Rape Accusation in Sweden
item.description: The WikiLeaks founder was interviewed by prosecutors in the 2010 case for the first time. He has been living in the Ecuadorean Embassy in Britain since 2012.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN and CHRISTINA ANDERSON

item.title: Critic of Malaysian Leader Is Sentenced for Disclosing Audit Information
item.media:description: Rafizi Ramli, a member of the People’s Justice Party.
item.description: The lawmaker was given 18 months in prison for revealing information from an audit into a government investment fund, from which billions of dollars are missing.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Sinosphere: ‘World’s Saddest Polar Bear’ to Get a Temporary Reprieve From Home in Chinese Mall
item.description: Amid public anger over his living conditions, a polar bear named Pizza will be moving from a mall aquarium while his quarters are upgraded.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Syrian Rebels Brace for a Trump Cutoff, and Look for a Silver Lining
item.media:description: Members from the Free Syrian Army take part in a battle in northern Syria last month against Islamic State fighters.
item.description: President-elect Donald J. Trump has suggested he will end support, which some groups hope would encourage Saudi Arabia and Turkey to provide more sophisticated weapons.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Narendra Modi Defends Currency Move as Millions in India Scramble for Cash
item.media:description: People waited to deposit their old high-denomination currency notes on Saturday outside a bank in Guwahati, India. Prime Minister Narendra Modi said last week that the public could get new large notes at banks, but customers have faced waits of many hours.
item.description: His voice quivering, the prime minister responded to biting criticism of his decision to ban large notes in circulation in an effort to fight corruption.
item.dc:creator: GEETA ANAND and HARI KUMAR

item.title: Bill to Legalize West Bank Settlements Advances in Israel
item.description: If approved by Parliament, legislation would transfer the rights for the use of private land into Israeli hands and force Palestinian landowners to accept compensation.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Windmills or Reactor Cores? Inside South Africa’s Energy Clash
item.media:description: The tower of Khi Solar One near Upington, South Africa. The plant has produced enough electricity to power 65,000 homes during the day.
item.description: The country is experiencing a boom in renewable energy, but some government officials are pushing instead for nuclear power to wean the nation off coal.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: European Leaders Gather to Grapple With Donald Trump’s Victory
item.media:description: Federica Mogherini is the foreign policy chief for the European Union.
item.description: European Union foreign ministers met on Sunday to discuss potential ramifications of Mr. Trump’s win. Many of his statements have left some European nations vulnerable.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER

item.title: Pro-Russia Candidate Appears Likely to Win Bulgarian Presidency
item.media:description: Campaign posters for Rumen Radev, an independent candidate for the presidency, in Sofia, Bulgaria.
item.description: Rumen Radev, a former air force commander with no previous political experience, seemed headed for a decisive victory in a runoff election.
item.dc:creator: BORYANA DZHAMBAZOVA, KIT GILLET and RICK LYMAN

item.title: Vancouver Journal: Canada’s Gay Curling Leagues Take Pride on Ice
item.media:description: A Pacific Rim Curling League game in Vancouver, British Columbia, in October. Gay curling leagues have blossomed in recent decades, highlighting a distinctly Canadian aspect of modern gay life.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: Gay players have added campy humor and flamboyantly themed tournaments to a winter sport’s traditions of friendly competition and drinking.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: From Bataclan to Street Cafes, Paris Is Quiet but Resolute as It Mourns on Anniversary of Attacks
item.media:description: Flowers were placed under a memorial plaque unveiled Sunday at La Belle Équipe, a cafe in Paris that was one of several sites attacked by Islamic State militants on Nov. 13, 2015.
item.description: A penetrating silence enveloped Paris on Sunday as thousands of people massed under a leaden sky to remember the victims of the Nov. 13, 2015, attacks.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN

item.title: Violence Escalates Between Myanmar Forces and Rohingya
item.media:description: Myanmar police officers patrolling last month in Maungdaw, Rakhine State, along the border with Bangladesh. The state has been under siege since armed assailants killed nine police officers in early October.
item.description: After two soldiers were killed by attackers, troops of the Buddhist-majority government burned villages in Rakhine State close to the Bangladesh border.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ and WAI MOE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Jakarta Protest, Tied to Faith, May Have Deeper Links to Secular Politics
item.media:description: The police guarded a parliamentary building during a protest against Jakarta’s governor, Basuki Tjahaja Purnama, this month.
item.description: Analysts say politicians are exploiting religious fervor to challenge the capital’s governor and his close ally, President Joko Widodo.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE

item.title: New Zealand Struck by Powerful Earthquake
item.media:description: People were evacuated from buildings along Dixon Street in Wellington.
item.description: The east coast of the South Island was shaken Monday just after midnight, with multiple aftershocks and tsunami waves.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Who Owns the Street in Mexico City?
item.description: Bicycle riders fight a daily battle for space with cars and drivers.
item.dc:creator: ANTONIO MARTÍNEZ

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: How Trump Is Good for China
item.media:description: A newspaper featuring a photo of president-elect Donald J. Trump, at a newsstand in Beijing.
item.description: The Chinese prefer a relationship with a United States that doesn’t impose its values on the world.
item.dc:creator: ERIC LI

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Australia’s Addiction to Coal
item.media:description: Coal being stockpiled at the coal port of Newcastle in New South Wales, Australia.
item.description: The country’s politicians say they want to reduce greenhouse-gas emissions while planning to build new coal mines.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD DENNISS

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Postscript: One Year Later, a Tip About a Border Crossing Pays Off
item.media:description: Laborers transported ammonium nitrate at the crossing from Akcakale, Turkey, into Syria in April 2015. The compound, a common fertilizer, has been used by terrorists to create explosives.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.description: How New York Times reporting may have made the Middle East just a little bit safer.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
